child.pub-comments: Population: 8,290 "McElhanon (Claassen and McElhanon 1970) identified five languages and noted that there is a great amount of dialectal variation in the Yupna valley. To these five languages Z'graggen (1973) added four more. A detailed survey is necessary, however, before a definitive statment can be made regarding the number and extent of th Yupna languages. The listing which follows is according to Z'graggen (1973)" (McElhanon 1975:541).

child.pub-comments: Population: 150 "It seems that Abaga is originally a Finisterre language whose speakers migrated south into the Kamano area and became subject to strong Kamano linguistic influence. They live in Kamano villages of Kose 1, Kose 2 and Kanofi containing the highest number of Abaga speakers. Only about a half dozen very old men are monolingual, all others bilingual Abaga and Kamano speakers, and Abaga appears to be rapidly receding before Kamano" (McElhanon 1975:543). According McElhanon, while Abaga seems to have its closest connection to the Erap and Uruwa families, it is assigned the status of an isolate of indeterminate family affiliationa within the Finisterre languages (1975:543).

child.pub-comments: Population: 6,130 "The Kâte language […] is one of the better recorded languages of Papua New Guinea (see Grube 1895; Dempwolff 1920; Flierl and Strauss 1976; Keysser 1925; McElhanon 1974; Pilhofer 1927a, 1927b and 1933; Johnson 1972; see also (III) 7.4.5.2)" (McElhanon 1975:529).

child.pub-comments: "In the days immediately preceding European contact, the Kâte people recognized five dialects of their language (Pilhofer 1928, 1929). The Lutheran Mission New Guinea, however, chose to promote a single dialect, Wemo (Wena), in its church and school programs. As a result, there are few speakers of the other dialects living today" (McElhanon 1975:529).
